data.title: [Windows 8] Visual flickering on WinRT
data.body: Hi, I previously converted DPSF over to support running on Android using DPSF (awesome!) and am now trying to do the same for WinRT.  I have it working and the particles show up, but all of the particles flicker (disappear and reappear quickly) A LOT.  They flicker both when I run the app in the "Simulator" and "Local Machine" mode.  I've tried using the latest dlls from the CodePlex download as well as pulling the latest code from the develop3d branch, both produce the same results.  Any ideas as to what is wrong?  Thanks!

data.title: Corrected GL.PixelStore calls
data.body: GL.PixelStore() calls in latest module used incorrect parameter types (All.UnpackAlignment instead of PixelStoreParameter.UnpackAlignment, for example), preventing the class library from compiling for Win7.

data.title: Error Adding MonoGame Content Builder Project
data.body:
STEPS TO REPRODUCE
Clean install of MonoGameInstaller-3.0.exe

Start VS2010 - 10.0.40219.1 SP1 Rel
Click new project...
Select "MonoGame" from Installed Templates
Select "MonoGame Application for Windows"
keep defaults
click "OK"

Right Click Solution in Solution Explorer
select ADD > New Project...
Select "MonoGame" from Installed Templates
Select "MonoGame Content Builder Project"
keep defaults
click "OK"

Error Shown
Microsoft Visual Studio dialog box
Message
The project file '<Path to content project file>' cannot be opened.
The project type is not supported by this installation.

ADDITIONAL
The content folder is created but empty.

data.title: Building content with VS2012
data.body:
I already posted at http://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/404412, but since this does appear to be an issue, I suppose it should appear here as well.

Right now, there is no 2012 Content Project out of the box. Documentation on the wiki is a bit outdated.

I managed to include a 2010 XNA project in the 2012 solution to trigger a content project build. It's a hack-ish solution with lots of issues and errors, but seems to be stitched just enough for my current needs.

There should be a proper 2012 MonoGame Windows Store App project with a Content Project.

data.title: Surface crashing sample
data.body:
Hi!

I'm linking a sample which crashes on Surface:

http://www.ru-zero.com/files2/crashingSample.zip

I think the problem is that when trying to access texture data which has a non multiple of 4 width crashes the Surface. It does not crash my computer nor simulator, only surface.

Thanks!
KakCAT

data.title: Set pixel unpacking alignment in Texture2D.SetData
data.body:
Fix attempt for issue #1028.
Set pixel unpacking alignment in Texture2D.SetData for uncompressed surface formats.  Should fix skewed textures when using 16-bit surface formats and an odd texture width.
Also added a missing SurfaceFormat.Bgr565 in GraphicsExtensions.Size().

data.title: Ignore mip maps for non power of two textures when device doesn't support them
data.body:
Added a GraphicsCapabilities class to test for non-power of two texture support. In the future this can be extended to test for other things. 

This feature is important because when you supply non PoT mip maps and the device doesn't support them, you will GL errors. Also, on Android some devices support them and others don't, meaning you may test your game and have it work fine but once released it will crash on other devices.

The support for mip maps with non-PoT textures is patchy, but more and more devices have support so it'd be a shame to disable it outright.

So far I've tested on an iPad 1, Windows 7, Android 4.0 Samsung GalaxyS2, and a MacBook (not pro).

The only part I'm not confident about is the handling of OPENGL non-GLES platforms (ie desktop PC, Mac and Linux). I took the advice given here: http://aras-p.info/blog/2012/10/17/non-power-of-two-textures/ (OpenGL section), which suggests a more reliable way of deciding on PoT support is whether the card supports 8192 sized textures. This is pretty safe. The only risk is that certain older devices that don't support 8192 textures but do fully support non-PoT textures will have their non-PoT mip maps discarded. Not likely to be a problem IMO as non PoT textures are mostly for UI elements and not likely to have mip maps anyway.

data.title: Improvements to handling of 16 bit textures
data.body:
Three changes here, all tested on Windows 7 (OPENGL), iOS and Android:

1) Added bit shifting code to support Bgra5551 textures in OPENGL platforms. Ironically I've decided not to use these textures as they look quite average. In any case, it works.
2) Fixed binding of Bgra4444 textures on Android.
3) Switched the Bgra4444 bit shifting to be for all OPENGL platforms (previous pull incorrectly added guards for GLES: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1029)

data.title: Modified error regex to match 2MGFX output
Improved iOS game loop/v-sync timing
data.body:
Note: This change needs some heavy testing before it's pulled in with the rest of it. It's a pretty big change that only touched a couple lines of code.

After a lot of experimentation, we found that we were hitting v-sync waits in our application. Since there's no option to disable v-sync, it was causing a significant FPS loss in some cases. I implemented the technique discussed here:  http://www.ananseproductions.com/game-loops-on-ios/

I'm open to any thoughts or suggestions, not sure if there's a better way we can get around having the DisplayLink's selector call Platform.Tick(), since whatever function CADisplayLink calls needs to be exported to ObjC.

data.title: Fix for BGRA4444 textures on non-GLES platforms
data.body: Fixed it for Windows 8. For iOS, there is some indexing issue. See #1028.

data.title: [iOS] Support for BGRA4444
data.body:
We just switched to BGRA4444 textures (with sourcerectangle).

Result on simulator (the background is PVRTC, the form is BGRA4444):
http://kepfeltoltes.hu/121126/4444_www.kepfeltoltes.hu_.png

Happens with textures of odd width.

Trying to load some textures results in a crash. Our loading screen loaded fine, but during the loading of the assets an unmanaged crash happens during the call at Texture2D.cs:359.

data.title: OpenGL Multiple Render Target Support
data.body: On OpenGL ES, or when there is only one render target, behavior remains unchanged. On OpenGL with more than one render target, it uses GL.DrawBuffers() to bind them.

data.title: Implemented Quaternion.ToString() method
Small fix when too many gamepads are connected
data.body: Otherwise it throws an ArgumentOutOfRange exception.

data.title: More MGFX Improvements
data.body:
Some more MGFX improvements and fixes:
- Added the missing rasterizer states to MGFX parser.
- Fixed the sampler and render states to not be case sensitive.
- MGFX parser understands the #line directive and correctly reports file and line numbers.
- The column in errors is now correct and no longer always 0.

data.title: [MonoDevelop Addin] 16 errors & 2 warnings when creating a brand new project.

First I want to say that everything builds fine from the monogame sources, so that's not the problem. As far as I know I'm placing every one of the dll files from the release folder in the addin section of MonoDevelop like I was told. For some reason it's not recognizing them. data.title: MGFX Cleanup
data.body: Just unused namespace and dead code removal.  No functional change.

data.title: 2MGFX produces shader with undeclared identifier.
MGFX Improvements
data.body:
A bunch of improvements to MGFX processing.
- The MGFX parser is now ignores case for FX keywords.
- Support of default values for HLSL shaders.
- We now have a good error message when the shader model is mismatched for the platform.
- We now show an error if there isn't a valid technique/pass in the effect.
- Updated MGFX version to 3...  this will force old MGFX files to be re-processed.

You can ignore the changes in ParseTree.cs, Parser.cs, and Scanner.cs as they are all automatically generated from MGFX.tpg.

Also I have some fixes to MonoGame.ContentPipeline.targets and removed unnecessary Imports.

data.title: MGFX Sampler and Render States - Take 2
data.body:
I don't think all sampler and render states are supported by the parser yet, but it just ignores any it doesn't recognize. In other words, it may not be done, but it shouldn't break anything.

The sampler state parsing depends on a pretty specific format (similar to `sampler Foo = sampler_state { };`). It works on all the default effects, and on the effects I use in my game. It's only been tested on Windows, however.

Note: this adds some things to the MGFX binary format. I recompiled the default effects. There are a few samples that will need XNBs recompiled. I already recompiled them to make sure they still work, but I think they'll have to be in another pull request.

Also note: I accidentally included a change to GraphicsDevice that should be in a separate pull request (multiple render targets) but reverted it back in another commit. Best way I could think to fix it.

I'm getting an error when my game tries to load a Song file from an mp3 in my Linux port (it worked fine with the Mac, iOS, and Android ports). It seems to be trying to play it as a wav but I'm not sure. Here's the stack trace:

data.title: Fix loading of compressed Xnb files in Android
data.body:
Seems this was broken due to an incorrect starting position offset being applied. This caused an out of bounds access in the buffer during decompression.

This fixes https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/640

data.title: Fixed the Content issue where the F# project project template was not pa...
data.body: ...ckaging the contents of the Content directory propery.  This is just the addition of an attribute to the template file.

I have a fairly complex shader which is failing to convert.

data.title: StorageDevice temporary fix for WINRT. Compiling.
OpenTK.Input.Key.BackSlash is now mapped to Keys.OemPipe
data.body: #1012 XNA 4.0 returns Keys.OemPipe for the backslash key.

data.title: Keyboard detection on Win7 incorrectly identifies OemBackslash when it should be OemPipe
data.body:
In XNA 4.0 OemPipe is detected when the \ key is pressed without the shift. Maybe this was a bug in XNA 4.0. But in MonoGame, OemBackslash is detected, not OemPipe.

The documentation at http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.input.keys.aspx does list OemBackslash as something specific to 102 key keyboards, which I'm pretty sure all US standard keyboards are 104 key keyboards since Win 95.

data.title: Fix StorageDevice compile error in WinRT
data.body: AsyncResult does not exist in WinRT.  Reverting back to previous code for WinRT so it at least compiles.

data.title: Issue with number of arithmetic instructions (2MGFX & MG-ContentProcessor)
data.body:
After : "2MGFX.exe 07.fx 07.mgfx" I got the following error:

Fatal exception when creating the effect!
SharpDX.CompilationException: (38,10): error X5608: Compiled shader code uses too many arithmetic instruction slots (65). Max. allowed by the target (ps_2_0) is 64.

   bei Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DXEffectObject.CreateShader(ShaderInfo shaderInfo, String shaderFunction, String shaderProfile, Boolean isVert
exShader) in t:\azureblack\ares_material\code\monogame\Tools\2MGFX\DXEffectObject.hlsl.cs:Zeile 190.
   bei Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DXEffectObject.FromShaderInfo(ShaderInfo shaderInfo) in t:\azureblack\ares_material\code\monogame\Tools\2MGFX
\DXEffectObject.hlsl.cs:Zeile 47.
   bei TwoMGFX.Program.Main(String[] args) in t:\azureblack\ares_material\code\monogame\Tools\2MGFX\Program.cs:Zeile 47.

However, in XNA the shader works fine.

PS: I converted ~40 shaders and only this one had serious issues ;-) Impressive! By the way, some shaders did not work in the first run because of "unexpected token, expected }" issues. However, after deleting some unnecessary spaces (or other non-printable chars) towards the end of the *.fx files, this was resolved quickly.
